#Text=Two Syrian journalists killed around New Year 's Day
#Text=Tuesday , January 3 , 2012

#Text=The last two journalists reported killed at the turn of the year were Syrians ; just at a time when protests and violence in the country are escalating , and the Arab League begins its initial assessment of the situation .
#Text=Shot on December 30 , and the first journalist to die in 2012 , was veteran journalist Shukri Ratib Abu Burghol .
#Text=The senior journalist was shot in the face after arriving home from work at a radio station in Darayya , on the southern outskirts of the capital city Damascus .
#Text=According to Reporters Without Borders , he died three days after the shooting at Al Mouwsat Hospital .
#Text=The Syrian uprising began 11 months ago with a " Day of Rage " on February 3 , last year .
#Text=Homs , north of Damascus , has been a flashpoint of the revolution .
#Text=Burghol , 56 , was a journalist for about 21 years , working for the newspaper Al-Thawra ( The Revolution ) whilst also hosting a weekly show for Radio Damascus .
#Text=A source told the Xinhua news agency
#Text=Burghol had received threats .
#Text=Basil Al-Sayed became the last journalist to die in 2011 , shot on December 29 by a sniper in the city of Homs .
#Text=The Arab League has confirmed that the Syrian government have been seen using snipers against protesters elsewhere in Daraa .
#Text=The shooting of Al-Sayed took place in the Bab Amr section of Homs .
#Text=The city has been one of the hot spots for protests against Bashar al-Assad 's government during 2011 .
#Text=In the last week of the year , the Bab Amr neighbourhood was attacked by the Syrian military and experienced heavy violence .
#Text=The 24-year-old camera operator was a citizen journalist who uploaded his videos to video-sharing sites to spread information about the protests .
#Text=Photojournalists and camera operators have been some of the the most at-risk during the Arab uprisings in Tunisia and Libya .
#Text=Ferzat Jarban — the first known journalist to be killed in Syria — was a freelance camera operator , arrested on November 19 whilst filming protests in Al-Qusayr , Homs Governorate .
#Text=He was found dead the following day .

#Text=In Syria , citizen journalists like Al-Sayed , and freelancers like Jarban , have been risking their lives by openly recording videos of protests which may serve as documentary evidence of human rights ' abuse .
#Text=Currently information is hard to verify and reliable independent sources are largely banned or restricted inside Syria .
#Text=Foreign journalists have been barred from the country , and from covering the protests .
#Text=HAVE YOUR SAY
#Text=What do you think of people risking their lives to get video footage of the Syrian protests ?
#Text=Add or view comments
#Text=At the end of 2011

#Text=Arab League observers had sent out observers to different cities in Syria to monitor the situation , whilst one of its advisers called for the organization to retreat after Al-Assad 's government reneged on agreements to halt the crackdown .

#Text=According to Navi Pillay , High Commissioner for Human Rights at the United Nations , more than 5,000 people have been killed during the Syrian uprising , a figure that includes around 300 children .
#Text=Three journalists are now known to have been killed in Syria .
#Text=In December , the Committee to Protect Journalists ( CPJ ) addressed an open letter to Syrian President Al-Assad calling for the release of all journalists in detention ;
#Text=the CPJ documented 29 cases of journalists being detained in 2011 .

#Text=The CPJ reported that 45 journalists were killed worldwide in 2011 , whereas — using differing criteria — Reporters Without Borders state that 66 journalists around the world died in 2011 , and assert that , by almost every indicator , violence and censorship against international journalists was worse in 2011 , up 16 % on their 2010 figures .
#Text=This story has updates
#Text=See Syrian citizen journalists risk death , targetted ; city of Homs facing starvation
